questiontext.text:
A sample was gathered.

ùê±=56.41,55.19,52.39,54.77,53.47,56.95,53.13,54.9,53.48,54.48,53.61\mathbf{x} = 56.41, 55.19, 52.39, 54.77, 53.47, 56.95, 53.13, 54.9, 53.48, 54.48, 53.61

You can download the data as a CSV file.

Determine x‚Äæ\bar{x}, the sample mean. Your answer can be rounded to the nearest tenth.

generalfeedback.text:
You need to sum the values (‚àëùê±\sum \mathbf{x}, see summation) and divide by the sample size (nn).

x‚Äæ=‚àëùê±n=598.7811=54.4345\bar{x} = \frac{\sum \mathbf{x}}{n} = \frac{598.78}{11} = 54.4345 You can round x‚Äæ\bar{x} to the nearest tenth: 54.4.

In a spreadsheet, you can use the AVERAGE function. You can see a solution spreadsheet here.

In R, you can use the MEAN function.

# First, get the csv into the working directory... then...
data = read.csv("get_mean.csv")
x = data$x
xbar = mean(x)
round(xbar,1)
## [1] 54.4

questiontext.text:
Depending on the type of distribution, we can make a strong claim regarding the mean and median.

  • Symmetric (bell, uniform, bimodal)
    • mean‚âàmedian\text{mean} \approx \text{median}
  • Skew-right
    • mean>median\text{mean} > \text{median}
  • Skew-left
    • mean<median\text{mean} < \text{median}

A sample was gathered and visualized with a histogram.


What claim can you make regarding the mean and median?

generalfeedback.text: The distribution is skew-left, so mean<median\text{mean} < \text{median}.

questiontext.text:
Depending on the type of distribution, we can make a strong claim regarding the mean and median.

  • Symmetric (bell, uniform, bimodal)
    • mean‚âàmedian\text{mean} \approx \text{median}
  • Skew-right
    • mean>median\text{mean} > \text{median}
  • Skew-left
    • mean<median\text{mean} < \text{median}

A sample was gathered and visualized with a histogram.


What claim can you make regarding the mean and median?

generalfeedback.text: The distribution is skew-right, so mean>median\text{mean} > \text{median}.
